[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Function: EntryABI::is_transaction_script_abi()] [ABI spoofing] Can is_transaction_script_abi() be fooled by crafted EntryABI values to incorrectly identify transaction types and route them to wrong execution paths? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Function: EntryABI::name()] [String injection] Does the name() method properly sanitize or validate the returned string, or can malicious ABI names contain control characters or escape sequences that exploit downstream processing? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Function: EntryABI::doc()] [Documentation injection] Can attackers inject malicious content in ABI documentation strings returned by doc() to exploit parsers, logging systems, or display components? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Function: EntryABI::ty_args()] [Type argument mismatch] Can an attacker exploit inconsistencies between ABI-declared type arguments in ty_args() and actual type arguments in Script/EntryFunction to bypass type checking? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Function: EntryABI::args()] [Argument count mismatch] Can attackers supply arguments that don't match the expected argument count from args(), causing undefined behavior or crashes during validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script, Serde] [Deserialization bomb] Can an attacker craft malicious serde_bytes serialization for Script.code that causes exponential memory allocation during deserialization? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction, Serde] [Vec_bytes deserialization] Does the vec_bytes serde helper for EntryFunction.args properly limit the size and number of byte vectors, or can attackers cause memory exhaustion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Equality bypass] Can attackers exploit the PartialEq/Eq implementation to create functionally different Scripts that compare as equal, bypassing deduplication or replay protection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Hash collision exploitation] Can attackers craft EntryFunction values with identical hashes but different semantics to exploit hash-based data structures in transaction pools or caches? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Debug trait] [Information disclosure] Does the Debug implementation for Script (showing hex-encoded code) leak sensitive bytecode information that aids in exploit development or competitive analysis? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Missing size validation] Since Script::new() accepts arbitrary vector sizes without validation, can attackers create transactions that exceed maximum transaction size limits, bypassing API-layer checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Bytecode verification gap] Does Script lack built-in bytecode verification, allowing invalid or malicious bytecode to pass through until VM execution, potentially crashing validators mid-consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Module existence check] Does EntryFunction::new() validate that the specified ModuleId actually exists, or can attackers reference non-existent modules causing downstream errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Function visibility bypass] Can attackers use EntryFunction to call private or internal functions that are not marked as entry points, bypassing intended access controls? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Argument type mismatch] Does EntryFunction allow mismatched argument types between the raw bytes in args and the expected function signature, potentially causing type confusion in the VM? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Clone cost attack] Can attackers repeatedly clone large Script objects to exhaust memory or CPU resources during transaction validation or mempool operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Hash computation cost] Can attackers craft Script values with expensive hash computations (due to large code/args) to slow down hash-based operations in mempool or storage? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Type resolution cost] Can attackers supply deeply nested or recursive TypeTag structures that cause expensive type resolution operations, degrading validator performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Argument parsing overhead] Can attackers craft EntryFunction args with maximum-size byte vectors that cause expensive BCS deserialization, slowing transaction processing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Type parameter exploit] Can attackers supply TypeTag values in Script.ty_args that exploit generic type instantiation bugs in the Move VM, causing crashes or undefined behavior? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [TransactionArgument encoding] Can attackers exploit the TransactionArgument encoding to inject values that violate Move's type safety invariants when deserialized? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Struct type confusion] Can attackers use TypeTag to reference struct types in ways that bypass Move's resource safety guarantees or enable resource duplication? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [Generic instantiation] Can attackers supply generic type arguments that cause exponential type instantiation or monomorphization, exhausting VM resources? (High)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: Script] [Non-deterministic execution] Can differences in Script deserialization or bytecode interpretation across validator nodes lead to non-deterministic execution and consensus failures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/types/src/transaction/script.rs] [Struct: EntryFunction] [State machine divergence] Can attackers craft EntryFunction calls that produce different results on different validators due to argument deserialization inconsistencies? (Critical)
